content: Hi @T-compiler/meeting; the triage meeting will start in about 1h30

WG-prioritization has done pre-triage in #t-compiler/wg-prioritization/alerts
and prepared the meeting agenda

We will have checkins from:

  • WG-rls2.0 checkin by @matklad
  • WG-self-profile checkin by @Wesley Wiser
p.s. for this meeting I've tried slimming down a bit the performance log reporting, please let me know if you like it better (other suggestions appreciated!)
Hi @T-compiler/meeting! Add a :wave: emoji to show you're here :)

we will start off with 5 minutes for ...

Announcements
• We have our planning meeting tomorrow (at 2021-01-15T10:00:00-05:00
(Meeting proposals encouraged: https://github.com/rust-lang/compiler-team/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aopen+label%3Ameeting-proposal )

• New MCPs (take a look, see if you like them!)
    • No new proposals this time.

• Old MCPs (not seconded, take a look)
    • "MCP: move compiler/ crates to stable Rust" compiler-team#358
    • "Add 32-bit and 64-bit stderr/stdout files for ui tests" compiler-team#365
    • "Add a NOOP_METHOD_CALL lint for methods which should never be directly called" compiler-team#375
    • "MCP: More Cranelift-friendly portable SIMD intrinsics" compiler-team#381
    • "Debuggable Macro Expansions" compiler-team#386
    • "Move query implementation outside rustc_middle" compiler-team#388
    • "Uplift the invalid_atomic_ordering lint from clippy to rustc" compiler-team#390
    • "Staged queries" compiler-team#391
    • "Do not traverse the HIR to generate metadata" compiler-team#392
    • "Embed version numbers in backport nominations and regression labels" compiler-team#393
    • "Add different entry points for x.py" compiler-team#396

• Pending FCP requests (check your boxes!)
    • "rustc: Stabilize -Zrun-dsymutil as -Csplit-debuginfo" rust#79570

• Things in FCP (make sure you're good with it)
    • "Make it easier to build the standard library" compiler-team#394
    • "Add a scheme to register functions from other crates with TyCtxt" compiler-team#395
    • "Remove PredicateKind in favor of only Binder<PredicateAtom>" compiler-team#397

• Accepted MCPs
    • "Make it easier to build the standard library" compiler-team#394
    • "Add a scheme to register functions from other crates with TyCtxt" compiler-team#395

• Finalized FCPs (disposition merge)
    • [T-libs] "Stabilize slice::strip_prefix and slice::strip_suffix" rust#77853
    • [T-libs] "Stabilize split_inclusive" rust#77858
(sorry about all the edits... "you had one job, Felix!")
Hey, @matklad , does @WG-rls2.0 have anything to report?
WG checkins
Yup!

@WG-self-profile checkin by @Wesley Wiser:

WG activity was light this cycle:

  • andjo403 fixed a bug in the tooling where blocked queries weren't being properly counted when rustc was compiled with parallel-compiler = true (measureme#148)
Okay maybe we'll circle back around to @matklad at the end, so we don't hold things up now.

Beta-nominations

T-compiler

• "Make sure rust-call errors occur correctly for traits" rust#79675
    • Opened by @Rune Tynan
    • @Esteban Küber approves backport
    • Fixes issue #79669, where an ICE was returned when checking an item that wasn't a function/closure
So to be clear, the ICE in this case only arises for code that is always first emits an error diagnostic?
@Esteban Küber ^ ?
Looking
Yes
While you're here, please review "rustc: Stabilize -Zrun-dsymutil as -Csplit-debuginfo" rust#79570 and check your box if you have time

(If the ICE arises even in non error cases, or can mask the error, then I would definitely be in favor of a backport. But if it's only for cases that already are first emitting an error, then the bar for backport is a little higher. But it might be fine.)

nagisa said:

While you're here, please review "rustc: Stabilize -Zrun-dsymutil as -Csplit-debuginfo" rust#79570 and check your box if you have time

interesting, I don't think that was on the agenda, but it probably should be, somewhere, right?
@apiraino is the above an oversight in our agenda-construction processx?
I believe that's later on the agenda.

pnkfelix said:

  • Pending FCP requests (check your boxes!)
    • "rustc: Stabilize -Zrun-dsymutil as -Csplit-debuginfo" rust#79570

^
oh oh , irght
ah right thanks @lcnr
@pnkfelix it is in the announcements above I just took opportunity to ask @Esteban Küber since they are around.
its true, it does get swallowed up
it's a bit easy to miss, yeah
especially since it doesn't call out the people who's boxed are unticked. Hmm.
(not sure if I want to ping specific people, but its something to consider.)
ANYWAY
re backport: I believe rust-call ABIs are fairly rarely used in explicit ways so I don't think its worth the backport
it also is really safe to backport though :laughing:
we've been living with ICEs for extern "rust-call" for ages and it came up very rarely.
It does look very low risk.
I am -1 on backport, I don't think we should be backporting things that don't affect stable users?
As far as I know `extern "rust-call" is unstable.
the problem is that the feature-gate checking itself is causing the ICE
If I understand correctly
so it "affects" stable users in that they are getting an ICE
yeah, errors on stable and causes an ice on beta
but since they are also getting the error message before that, I'm going with letting it slide as well.
I agree this is pretty borderline
lets just say decline for backport
it may be low risk, but it seems even lower value
yeah I'm not personally inclined to backport things regardless of risk
like, just not worth even small risk
The only reason I would back port is if it affects analyser negatively
And often enough
But given how long we've gone without a report, it isn't a common occurrence
I think I often need a reminder about this: does rust-analyzer respond much worse to ICE's than to "normal" compiler diagnostic messages?
(I assume rust-analyzer is what @Esteban Küber is referring to there)
anyway I'm going to decline and I'll let matklad spend time at the end telling me why I'm wrong at the end of teh meeting. :)

libs-impl

  • No beta nominations for libs-impl this time.

T-rustdoc

  • No beta nominations for T-rustdoc this time.

Stable-nominations

T-compiler

  • No stable nominations for T-compiler this time.

libs-impl

  • No stable nominations for libs-impl this time.

T-rustdoc

  • No stable nominations for T-rustdoc this time.

PRs S-waiting-on-team

T-compiler

  • No PRs waiting on T-compiler this time.

libs-impl

  • No PRs waiting on libs-impl this time.

Issues of Note

Short Summary

  • 0 T-compiler P-critical issues
    • 0 of those are unassigned
  • 58 T-compiler P-high issues
    • 37 of those are unassigned
  • 0 P-critical, 5 P-high, 2 P-medium, 0 P-low regression-from-stable-to-beta
  • 0 P-critical, 0 P-high, 7 P-medium, 1 P-low regression-from-stable-to-nightly
  • 0 P-critical, 37 P-high, 83 P-medium, 9 P-low regression-from-stable-to-stable

P-critical

T-compiler

  • No P-critical issues for T-compiler this time.
libs-impl

• "Heap buffer overflow in read_to_end_with_reservation()" rust#80894
    • Opened by @Yechan Bae
    • unsoundness causing a heap overflow
    • possible culprit on commit ecbb896
    • @Steven Fackler prepared PR #80895
    • issue probably will be mentioned in a CVE
it seems like this is being handled

(which reminds me: A good meeting proposal for tomorrow might be to revisit the libs-impl team structure we adopted. A rep from T-libs told me that team seems to be handling implementation stuff well.)
(so we might want to explicitly take it off our plate. We can discuss in a steering meeting.)
clarification:
that our team?
that libs team?
sorry
A rep from T-libs told me T-libs is handling implementation concerns
I see
Seems positive!
yep
I think libs is going to file an MCP soon
regarding the libs-impl stuff you mean, @simulacrum ?
yeah
that's a cool use of the MCP process.

T-rustdoc

  • No P-critical issues for T-rustdoc this time.

P-high regressions

P-high beta regressions

• "Cross-compiling Rust to s390x yields a faulty toolchain" rust#80810
    • Opened by Jakob-Naucke
    • not yet assigned
    • seems to affect specific s390x or to be related to endianess
    • @Santiago Pastorino suggests testing again against PR #80732 (ready for review)
To be clear: the PR has been tested against Diesel, but not against the bug described in rust#80810
Does anyone know if this is something that can be readily tested via cross-compilation?
It seems like it, from the bug description
So its just a matter of someone double-checking that PR #80732 does indeed fix the problem.
I'm willing to self-assign.
for that task
next

• "regression 1.50: Borrow checker reports function param as not living long enough" rust#80949
    • opened by @rylev, emerged in crater run for 1.50
    • Smallest MCVE found points to PR #78373
    • @Matthew Jasper mentions that pr #78373 is possibly leading to a less precise borrowcheck on how long the borrow lasts
(more specifically, @Matthew Jasper 's comment is that PR #78373 caused MIR to have one fewer basic block ... which reduced borrowck precision ... which I find fascinating...)
is mir borrowck precise to a basic block, rather than a statement?
I thought it must have at least statement-level granularity
So a livetime needs to go from live to not live to live again in a between the (start of the) terminator of one block and the start of the successor block.
I thought dataflow analyses don't generally care about whether there are more or fewer blocks, other than the fact that they remember facts at basic block boundaries for efficiency purposes.
I can believe causing two blocks to become one could reduce precision
(two successor blocks, that is)
@Matthew Jasper is that what's going on?
Oh I see, so the problem really is not that we have fewer blocks, but that there's a statement that has too much implicit behaviour?
interesting
There's an intermediate block that has been removed.
so, how bad is this
That is: This meeting is (unfortunately) not good place to dive deep into details of dataflow analysis
but it is the right place to try to figure out severity of this
Right, so: the PR fixes a bug
I'll try a few things out for this. But reverting the original PR is an option.
https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/47949
@Matthew Jasper do you have a more detailed write-up available somewhere?
if we revert we prevent the regression (which seems quite serious) while bringing back a bug that is in 47xxxs
bug is soundness bug though
I am not inclined to revert, though scope of regression in terms of affected programs
is also unclear
I don't. I can make a write up if that would help.
I'd appreciate it
It was never totally established if #47949 is a soundness bug
If nothing else just showing the relevant MIR :)
It is, imo
yeah, it isn't clear to me that its a soundness bug either.
see this comment, for example
At some point we will need to be clearer about our guarantees regarding drops and panics
yes
Okay. anyway, I think it seems worthwhile to invest some effort into fixing this without reverting PR #78373
I mostly am curious about the scenario where we don't find a fix
before the next release
in that scenario, do we revert #78373?
another Q: how many crates regression has affected?
I think reverting would be ok, but it would depend a bit yes on how many crates are affected.
if its just 1 crate, I think we could consider working with the crate author to work around this regression in their crate.
okay, lets maybe tabel the question of a revert for later, after we get more data about impact regression has on ecosystem
lets move forward on agenda then

• "regression 1.50: deny after forbid breaks build" rust#80988
    • Opened by @rylev, emerged in crater run for 1.50
    • possibly related to issue #77713
    • @simulacrum self assigns this issue and points to PR #78864 and check that against the crates breaking in this issue
(@Matthew Jasper, to clarify, are you going to be investigating how to fix?)
Yes
that is not the right summary I think of what I said - I am going to figure out if the regressions here seem expected and nominate for t-lang probably

nagisa said:

another Q: how many crates regression has affected?

There was only one crate effected by the issue in https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/80949
Was #80949 found via a crater run?
yes
oh yeah, it links directly to the report itself, okay.
(Can someone add a hyperlink onto issue #80949 description, linking to the PR with the try + crater run on it ?)
@simulacrum are these regressions only on leaf crates?
(that is my assumption)
should be unless my PR is buggy
but I've assigned to investigate
okay. sounds under control then.

Unassigned P-high nightly regressions

  • No unassigned P-high nightly regressions this time.

pnkfelix said:

(Can someone add a hyperlink onto issue #80949 description, linking to the PR with the try + crater run on it ?)

found via beta run to be clear, we should make that part of that process
beta runs are done via github PR's, right?
or is there different infrastructure for those runs?
issues
okay, I can follow up with @simulacrum for more clarity on all that, won't spend further mtg on it.

Performance logs

2021-01-12 Triage full report

Overall, a positive albeit quiet week. The largest change came from the incremental compilation working group which delivered large gains in performance caused by changes in how inlining is handled in debug mode. Unfortunately, these changes may be reversed due to concerns.

Triage done by @rylev.

1 Regressions, 2 Improvements, 3 Mixed 2 of them in rollups

Regressions

Rollup of 9 pull requests #80867

  • Moderate regression in instruction counts (up to 1.7% on incr-full builds of syn-opt)
  • Minor regressions in mostly incremental builds (both opt and debug).
  • It's hard to tell which PR was responsible but #79968 seems to be the most likely. We will investigate.
  • There was a change in the impl_trait_ref which may give hints as to the root cause.

Improvements

  • Rollup of 9 pull requests #80928
  • Do not query the HIR directly in opt_associated_item. #80889

Mixed

  • Do not make local copies of inline fns in debug mode #76896
  • ast: Remove some indirection layers from values in key-value attributes #80441
  • Serialize incr comp structures to file via fixed-size buffer #80463
(wg-incr-comp is going to revert PR #76896 , I believe.)
(though I don't remember checking if someone has that task; @Wesley Wiser , do you know if @Santiago Pastorino is planning on doing that...?)

Nags requiring follow up

  • Follow up needs to happen on the regressions, especially on the rollup #80928 and #80441 where the performance regressed from an early perf run done while the PR was still open.
We did attribute some regression to https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/79968/, but decided to keep the change because it improves debugging story

pnkfelix said:

(though I don't remember checking if someone has that task; Wesley Wiser , do you know if Santiago Pastorino is planning on doing that...?)

This already landed (#80922).
did it? I skimmed the PR and didn't see any links from revert PR
oh I see it now
okay
See the https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/80947 for context on #79968
okay, onward

Nominated Issues

T-compiler

  • No nominated issues for T-compiler this time.

libs-impl

  • No nominated issues for libs-impl this time.

RFC

  • "RFC: Checking conditional compilation at compile time" rfcs#3013
(we don't have a good process for ensuring the perf triage is updated as progress is made on addressing issues. We sometimes go back and update the report, but I did not do that this week)
We did discuss rfc#3013 last week a little, right?
Yeah :thumbs_up:
oh I'll check why it didnt make into the agenda
right. I even implied in that discussion that I would go and look and decide whether to FCP
I'm planning to re-read it this weekend and start an FCP to merge unless I find major issues or someone beats me to it
@apiraino it was on agenda, and I'm not saying it doesn't belong on agenda
right (sorry)
I just like to say redundant things from time to time. People tell me I should do it more often.
So I don't think there's anything we need to discuss live about rfc#3013
beyond "go look at it, y'all", again.

rylev said:

(we don't have a good process for ensuring the perf triage is updated as progress is made on addressing issues. We sometimes go back and update the report, but I did not do that this week)

this might be a good thing to have a design meeting about, maybe.
(meeting proposals welcome, y'all!)
I'm sure at some point "y'all" will come naturally to my New England voice...
Anyway: Its good that we're at the end of our agenda, because I promised matklad time at the end
@matklad ^

rls-2.0 also have been pretty quiet lately.
This means that there are a lot of improvements all over the place, but nothing particularly earth-shattering happened.
We did ship on-the-fly (during completion) auto-imports.
We are also in the process of yet-another redesign of the core syntax tree datastructure: https://github.com/rust-analyzer/rust-analyzer/issues/6857.

The parser library-ification work is sadly on-hold :-[

Finally, to re-invigorate more ambitious undertakings, we will now hold a rust-analyzer steering meeting every six weeks.
The first one will happen next Monday, check the t-compiler calendar for details.

Finally, to re-invigorate more ambitious undertakings, we will now hold a rust-analyzer steering meeting every six weeks.

This seems like a really good idea!
@matklad do you have any comments on whether we should reconsider our prioritization of beta-backports of ICE-fixing PR's ?
@matklad do the steering meetings have a distinct calendar event?
(in terms of the impact of ICE's on rust-analyzer, that is)
(I want to add myself to them so I don't forget...)
@nikomatsakis yes
@pnkfelix not sure I understand...
Sorry, I'll establish better context
Sadly, we are still separate codebases...,
During earlier discussion of whether to backport a PR to the beta channel
@Esteban Küber raised the question of whether an ICE is more problematic for "analyser" (more problematic than a normal error diagnostic, that is)

We did ship on-the-fly (during completion) auto-imports.

this is super awesome btw
Now that I'm more awake I'm thinking that rls was always affected (crashing completely)

From that, combined with vague recollections of my own, I took it that rust-analyzer misbehaves in some way , or is less performant, etc, when the compiler ICE's on input that rust-analyzer hands to it ...
... oh @Esteban Küber you were talking about RLS ??
While I'm not sure about rust-analyzer s behavior in the case of ICEs
Just now realized that my mind was conflating the two possibly incorrectly in my fear of ICEs
@matklad (I know the code bases are separate; but rust-analyzer still calls out to rustc for some actions, right?)
rustc ICEs don't affect rust-analyzer in any special way
Great! That is what I was expecting.
Yay for process separation.
okay that's the hour y'all
Thanks to everyone in @T-compiler/meeting for attending. Stay safe, stay healthy, seek out things that spark joy in your life.

Next week's agenda is online at:
https://hackmd.io/33X8izU-S2G-i-dIPBQS1w?view

Scheduled checkins:

  • WG-traits checkin by @nikomatsakis and @Jack Huey

by the way, I think I need a small fix on my account for the HackMD Rust compiler team permissions, I can't set ownership to the team of the files I create.
(if anyone can help me out :pray: thanks)

I think that should be

WG-traits checkin by @nikomatsakis and @Jack Huey
sorry typo, thanks

apiraino said:

by the way, I think I need a small fix on my account for the HackMD Rust compiler team permissions, I can't set ownership to the team of the files I create.
(if anyone can help me out :pray: thanks)

We resolved this :smile:
